date_time_create_from_format_call.summary: The first argument of `DateTime::createFromFormat` method must start with `!`.
date_time_create_from_format_call.description:
Consider this code:
    `DateTime::createFromFormat('Y-m-d', '2022-02-11')`.
    What value will be returned? '2022-02-11 00:00:00.0'?
    No, actual return value has 'H:i:s' section like '2022-02-11 16:55:37.0'.
    Change 'Y-m-d' to '!Y-m-d', return value will be '2022-02-11 00:00:00.0'.
    So, adding `!` to format string will make return value more intuitive.
date_time_create_from_format_call.riskyDescription: Risky when depending on the actual timings being used even when not explicit set in format.

date_time_immutable.summary: Class `DateTimeImmutable` should be used instead of `DateTime`.
date_time_immutable.riskyDescription: Risky when the code relies on modifying `DateTime` objects or if any of the `date_create*` functions are overridden.

escape_implicit_backslashes.summary: Escape implicit backslashes in strings and heredocs to ease the understanding of which are special chars interpreted by PHP and which not.
escape_implicit_backslashes.description:
In PHP double-quoted strings and heredocs some chars like `n`, `$` or `u` have special meanings if preceded by a backslash (and some are special only if followed by other special chars), while a backslash preceding other chars are interpreted like a plain backslash. The precise list of those special chars is hard to remember and to identify quickly: this fixer escapes backslashes that do not start a special interpretation with the char after them.
It is possible to fix also single-quoted strings: in this case there is no special chars apart from single-quote and backslash itself, so the fixer simply ensure that all backslashes are escaped. Both single and double backslashes are allowed in single-quoted strings, so the purpose in this context is mainly to have a uniformed way to have them written all over the codebase.

explicit_indirect_variable.summary: Add curly braces to indirect variables to make them clear to understand.

explicit_string_variable.summary: Converts implicit variables into explicit ones in double-quoted strings or heredoc syntax.
explicit_string_variable.description:
The reasoning behind this rule is the following:
- When there are two valid ways of doing the same thing, using both is confusing, there should be a coding standard to follow.
- PHP manual marks `"$var"` syntax as implicit and `"{$var}"` syntax as explicit: explicit code should always be preferred.
- Explicit syntax allows word concatenation inside strings, e.g. `"{$var}IsAVar"`, implicit doesn't.
- Explicit syntax is easier to detect for IDE/editors and therefore has colors/highlight with higher contrast, which is easier to read.
Backtick operator is skipped because it is harder to handle; you can use `backtick_to_shell_exec` fixer to normalize backticks to strings.

final_class.summary: All classes must be final, except abstract ones and Doctrine entities.
final_class.description: No exception and no configuration are intentional. Beside Doctrine entities and of course abstract classes, there is no single reason not to declare all classes final. If you want to subclass a class, mark the parent class as abstract and create two child classes, one empty if necessary: you'll gain much more fine grained type-hinting. If you need to mock a standalone class, create an interface, or maybe it's a value-object that shouldn't be mocked at all. If you need to extend a standalone class, create an interface and use the Composite pattern. If these rules are too strict for you, you can use `FinalInternalClassFixer` instead.

{
    /**
     * @var \Foo\Bar\Baz

     */

    }

        catch (\Foo\SomeException $e) {}
    }
}

Changing variables to `null` instead of unsetting means these still show up when looping over class variables and reference properties remain unbroken. Since PHP 7.4, this rule might introduce `null` assignments to properties whose type declaration does not allow it.

php_unit_mock.summary: Usages of `->getMock` and `->getMockWithoutInvokingTheOriginalConstructor` methods MUST be replaced by `->createMock` or `->createPartialMock` methods.
php_unit_mock.riskyDescription: Risky when PHPUnit classes are overridden or not accessible, or when project has PHPUnit incompatibilities.

codeSamples.from:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    public function testFoo()
    {
        $mock = $this->getMockWithoutInvokingTheOriginalConstructor("Foo");
        $mock1 = $this->getMock("Foo");
        $mock1 = $this->getMock("Bar", ["aaa"]);
        $mock1 = $this->getMock("Baz", ["aaa"], ["argument"]); // version with more than 2 params is not supported
    }
}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    public function testFoo()
    {
        $mock = $this->createMock("Foo");
        $mock1 = $this->createMock("Foo");
        $mock1 = $this->createPartialMock("Bar", ["aaa"]);
        $mock1 = $this->getMock("Baz", ["aaa"], ["argument"]); // version with more than 2 params is not supported
    }
}

codeSamples.from:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    public function testFoo()
    {
        $mock1 = $this->getMock("Foo");
        $mock1 = $this->getMock("Bar", ["aaa"]); // version with multiple params is not supported
    }
}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    public function testFoo()
    {
        $mock1 = $this->createMock("Foo");
        $mock1 = $this->getMock("Bar", ["aaa"]); // version with multiple params is not supported
    }
}

php_unit_mock_short_will_return.summary: Usage of PHPUnit's mock e.g. `->will($this->returnValue(..))` must be replaced by its shorter equivalent such as `->willReturn(...)`.
php_unit_mock_short_will_return.riskyDescription: Risky when PHPUnit classes are overridden or not accessible, or when project has PHPUnit incompatibilities.

codeSamples.from:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    public function testSomeTest()
    {
        $someMock = $this->createMock(Some::class);
        $someMock->method("some")->will($this->returnSelf());
        $someMock->method("some")->will($this->returnValue("example"));
        $someMock->method("some")->will($this->returnArgument(2));
        $someMock->method("some")->will($this->returnCallback("str_rot13"));
        $someMock->method("some")->will($this->returnValueMap(["a","b","c"]));
    }
}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    public function testSomeTest()
    {
        $someMock = $this->createMock(Some::class);
        $someMock->method("some")->willReturnSelf();
        $someMock->method("some")->willReturn("example");
        $someMock->method("some")->willReturnArgument(2);
        $someMock->method("some")->willReturnCallback("str_rot13");
        $someMock->method("some")->willReturnMap(["a","b","c"]);
    }
}

configuration.name: target
configuration.description: Target version of PHPUnit.

php_unit_namespaced.summary: PHPUnit classes MUST be used in namespaced version, e.g. `\PHPUnit\Framework\TestCase` instead of `\PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase`.
php_unit_namespaced.description:
PHPUnit v6 has finally fully switched to namespaces.
You could start preparing the upgrade by switching from non-namespaced TestCase to namespaced one.
Forward compatibility layer (`\PHPUnit\Framework\TestCase` class) was backported to PHPUnit v4.8.35 and PHPUnit v5.4.0.
Extended forward compatibility layer (`PHPUnit\Framework\Assert`, `PHPUnit\Framework\BaseTestListener`, `PHPUnit\Framework\TestListener` classes) was introduced in v5.7.0.
php_unit_namespaced.riskyDescription: Risky when PHPUnit classes are overridden or not accessible, or when project has PHPUnit incompatibilities.

codeSamples.from:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    public function testSomething()
    {
        PHPUnit_Framework_Assert::assertTrue(true);
    }
}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit\Framework\TestCase
{
    public function testSomething()
    {
        PHPUnit\Framework\Assert::assertTrue(true);
    }
}

codeSamples.from:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{

        PHPUnit_Framework_Assert::assertTrue(true);
    }
}
codeSamples.to:

final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit\Framework\TestCase
{

    {
        PHPUnit_Framework_Assert::assertTrue(true);
    }
}

configuration.name: target
configuration.description: Target version of PHPUnit.

configuration.name: use_class_const
configuration.description: Use ::class notation.

php_unit_no_expectation_annotation.summary: Usages of `@expectedException*` annotations MUST be replaced by `->setExpectedException*` methods.
php_unit_no_expectation_annotation.riskyDescription: Risky when PHPUnit classes are overridden or not accessible, or when project has PHPUnit incompatibilities.

codeSamples.from:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    /**
     * @expectedException FooException
     * @expectedExceptionMessageRegExp /foo.*$/
     * @expectedExceptionCode 123
     */
    function testAaa()
    {
        aaa();
    }
}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    /**
     */
    function testAaa()
    {
        $this->setExpectedExceptionRegExp(\FooException::class, '/foo.*$/', 123);

        aaa();
    }
}

codeSamples.from:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    /**
     * @expectedException FooException
     * @expectedExceptionCode 123
     */
    function testBbb()
    {
        bbb();
    }

    /**
     * @expectedException FooException
     * @expectedExceptionMessageRegExp /foo.*$/
     */
    function testCcc()
    {
        ccc();
    }
}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    /**
     */
    function testBbb()
    {
        $this->setExpectedException(\FooException::class, null, 123);

        bbb();
    }

    /**
     * @expectedException FooException
     * @expectedExceptionMessageRegExp /foo.*$/
     */
    function testCcc()
    {
        ccc();
    }
}

php_unit_set_up_tear_down_visibility.summary: Changes the visibility of the `setUp()` and `tearDown()` functions of PHPUnit to `protected`, to match the PHPUnit TestCase.
php_unit_set_up_tear_down_visibility.riskyDescription: This fixer may change functions named `setUp()` or `tearDown()` outside of PHPUnit tests, when a class is wrongly seen as a PHPUnit test.

codeSamples.from:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    private $hello;
    public function setUp()
    {
        $this->hello = "hello";
    }

    public function tearDown()
    {
        $this->hello = null;
    }
}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    private $hello;
    protected function setUp()
    {
        $this->hello = "hello";
    }

    protected function tearDown()
    {
        $this->hello = null;
    }
}

configuration.name: group

php_unit_size_class.summary: All PHPUnit test cases should have `@small`, `@medium` or `@large` annotation to enable run time limits.
php_unit_size_class.description: The special groups [small, medium, large] provides a way to identify tests that are taking long to be executed.

configuration.name: assertions

php_unit_strict.summary: PHPUnit methods like `assertSame` should be used instead of `assertEquals`.
php_unit_strict.riskyDescription: Risky when any of the functions are overridden or when testing object equality.

codeSamples.from:
<?php
final class MyTest extends \PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
{
    public function testSomeTest()
    {
        $this->assertAttributeEquals(a(), b());
        $this->assertAttributeNotEquals(a(), b());
        $this->assertEquals(a(), b());
        $this->assertNotEquals(a(), b());
    }
}
codeSamples.to:

{
    public function testSomeTest()
    {
        $this->assertAttributeSame(a(), b());
        $this->assertAttributeNotSame(a(), b());
        $this->assertSame(a(), b());
        $this->assertNotSame(a(), b());
    }
}

configuration.name: align

configuration.name: spacing
configuration.description: Spacing between tag, hint, comment, signature, etc. You can set same spacing for all tags using a positive integer or different spacings for different tags using an associative array of positive integers `['tagA' => spacingForA, 'tagB' => spacingForB]`. If you want to define default spacing to more than 1 space use `_default` key in config array, e.g.: `['tagA' => spacingForA, 'tagB' => spacingForB, '_default' => spacingForAllOthers]`.

configuration.name: tags
configuration.description: The tags that should be aligned. Allowed values are tags with name (`'param', 'property', 'property-read', 'property-write', 'phpstan-param', 'phpstan-property', 'phpstan-property-read', 'phpstan-property-write', 'phpstan-assert', 'phpstan-assert-if-true', 'phpstan-assert-if-false', 'psalm-param', 'psalm-param-out', 'psalm-property', 'psalm-property-read', 'psalm-property-write', 'psalm-assert', 'psalm-assert-if-true', 'psalm-assert-if-false'`), tags with method signature (`'method', 'phpstan-method', 'psalm-method'`) and any custom tag with description (e.g. `@tag <desc>`).

pow_to_exponentiation.riskyDescription: Risky when the function `pow` is overridden.

protected_to_private.summary: Converts `protected` variables and methods to `private` where possible.

    }

configuration.name: dir
configuration.description: If provided, the directory where the project code is placed.

psr_autoloading.summary: Classes must be in a path that matches their namespace, be at least one namespace deep and the class name should match the file name.
psr_autoloading.riskyDescription: This fixer may change your class name, which will break the code that depends on the old name.

configuration.name: replacements
configuration.description: Mapping between replaced functions with the new ones.

random_api_migration.summary: Replaces `rand`, `srand`, `getrandmax` functions calls with their `mt_*` analogs or `random_int`.
random_api_migration.riskyDescription: Risky when the configured functions are overridden. Or when relying on the seed based generating of the numbers.

regular_callable_call.summary: Callables must be called without using `call_user_func*` when possible.
regular_callable_call.riskyDescription: Risky when the `call_user_func` or `call_user_func_array` function is overridden or when are used in constructions that should be avoided, like `call_user_func_array('foo', ['bar' => 'baz'])` or `call_user_func($foo, $foo = 'bar')`.

return_assignment.summary: Local, dynamic and directly referenced variables should not be assigned and directly returned by a function or method.

return_to_yield_from.summary: If the function explicitly returns an array, and has the return type `iterable`, then `yield from` must be used instead of `return`.

configuration.name: space_before
configuration.description: Spacing to apply before colon.

return_type_declaration.summary: Adjust spacing around colon in return type declarations and backed enum types.

self_accessor.summary: Inside class or interface element `self` should be preferred to the class name itself.
self_accessor.riskyDescription: Risky when using dynamic calls like get_called_class() or late static binding.

codeSamples.from:

{

    const BAR = Sample::BAZ;

    public function getBar()
    {
        return Sample::BAR;
    }
}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
class Sample
{
    const BAZ = 1;
    const BAR = self::BAZ;

    public function getBar()
    {
        return self::BAR;
    }
}

self_static_accessor.summary: Inside an enum or `final`/anonymous class, `self` should be preferred over `static`.

}

{

    }

    {
        return 'test';
    }
}

set_type_to_cast.riskyDescription: Risky when the `settype` function is overridden or when used as the 2nd or 3rd expression in a `for` loop .

short_scalar_cast.summary: Cast `(boolean)` and `(integer)` should be written as `(bool)` and `(int)`, `(double)` and `(real)` as `(float)`, `(binary)` as `(string)`.

simple_to_complex_string_variable.summary: Converts explicit variables in double-quoted strings and heredoc syntax from simple to complex format (`${` to `{$`).
simple_to_complex_string_variable.description: Doesn't touch implicit variables. Works together nicely with `explicit_string_variable`.

simplified_if_return.summary: Simplify `if` control structures that return the boolean result of their condition.

simplified_null_return.summary: A return statement wishing to return `void` should not return `null`.

single_blank_line_before_namespace.summary: There should be exactly one blank line before a namespace declaration.

standardize_increment.summary: Increment and decrement operators should be used if possible.

configuration.name: stick_comment_to_next_continuous_control_statement
configuration.description: Last comment of code block counts as comment for next block.

<?php
        // foo

    echo "foo";
        // this is treated as comment of `if` block, as `stick_comment_to_next_continuous_control_statement` is disabled

}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
// foo

    echo "foo";
    // this is treated as comment of `if` block, as `stick_comment_to_next_continuous_control_statement` is disabled
} else {
    $aaa = 1;
}

codeSamples.from:
<?php
        // foo
if ($foo) {
    echo "foo";
        // this is treated as comment of `elseif(1)` block, as `stick_comment_to_next_continuous_control_statement` is enabled
} elseif(1) {
    echo "bar";
} elseif(2) {
        // this is treated as comment of `elseif(2)` block, as the only content of that block
} elseif(3) {
    $aaa = 1;
        // this is treated as comment of `elseif(3)` block, as it is a comment in the final block
}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
// foo
if ($foo) {
    echo "foo";
// this is treated as comment of `elseif(1)` block, as `stick_comment_to_next_continuous_control_statement` is enabled
} elseif(1) {
    echo "bar";
} elseif(2) {
    // this is treated as comment of `elseif(2)` block, as the only content of that block
} elseif(3) {
    $aaa = 1;
    // this is treated as comment of `elseif(3)` block, as it is a comment in the final block
}

static_lambda.summary: Lambdas not (indirectly) referencing `$this` must be declared `static`.
static_lambda.riskyDescription: Risky when using `->bindTo` on lambdas without referencing to `$this`.

static_private_method.summary: Converts private methods to `static` where possible.
static_private_method.riskyDescription: Risky when the method: contains dynamic generated calls to the instance, is dynamically referenced, is referenced inside a Trait the class uses.

strict_comparison.riskyDescription: Changing comparisons to strict might change code behaviour.

strict_param.summary: Functions should be used with `$strict` param set to `true`.
strict_param.description: The functions "array_keys", "array_search", "base64_decode", "in_array" and "mb_detect_encoding" should be used with $strict param.
strict_param.riskyDescription: Risky when the fixed function is overridden or if the code relies on non-strict usage.

codeSamples.to:
<?php
$a = array_keys($b);
$a = array_search($b, $c, true);
$a = base64_decode($b, true);
$a = in_array($b, $c, true);

configuration.name: double_quoted
configuration.description: Whether to escape backslashes in double-quoted strings.

configuration.name: heredoc
configuration.description: Whether to escape backslashes in heredoc syntax.

configuration.name: single_quoted
configuration.description: Whether to escape backslashes in single-quoted strings.

string_implicit_backslashes.summary: Handles implicit backslashes in strings and heredocs. Depending on the chosen strategy, it can escape implicit backslashes to ease the understanding of which are special chars interpreted by PHP and which not (`escape`), or it can remove these additional backslashes if you find them superfluous (`unescape`). You can also leave them as-is using `ignore` strategy.
string_implicit_backslashes.description:
In PHP double-quoted strings and heredocs some chars like `n`, `$` or `u` have special meanings if preceded by a backslash (and some are special only if followed by other special chars), while a backslash preceding other chars are interpreted like a plain backslash. The precise list of those special chars is hard to remember and to identify quickly: this fixer escapes backslashes that do not start a special interpretation with the char after them.
It is possible to fix also single-quoted strings: in this case there is no special chars apart from single-quote and backslash itself, so the fixer simply ensure that all backslashes are escaped. Both single and double backslashes are allowed in single-quoted strings, so the purpose in this context is mainly to have a uniformed way to have them written all over the codebase.

codeSamples.from:
<?php

$singleQuoted = 'String with \" and My\Prefix\\';

$doubleQuoted = "Interpret my \n but not my \a";

$hereDoc = <<<HEREDOC
Interpret my \100 but not my \999
HEREDOC;

$singleQuoted = 'String with \" and My\Prefix\\';

$doubleQuoted = "Interpret my \n but not my \\a";

Interpret my \100 but not my \\999
HEREDOC;

string_length_to_empty.summary: String tests for empty must be done against `''`, not with `strlen`.
string_length_to_empty.riskyDescription: Risky when `strlen` is overridden, when called using a `stringable` object, also no longer triggers warning when called using non-string(able).

string_line_ending.summary: All multi-line strings must use correct line ending.
string_line_ending.riskyDescription: Changing the line endings of multi-line strings might affect string comparisons and outputs.

stringable_for_to_string.summary: A class that implements the `__toString()` method must explicitly implement the `Stringable` interface.

codeSamples.to:
<?php
class Foo implements \Stringable
{
    public function __toString()
    {
        return "Foo";
    }
}

switch_case_semicolon_to_colon.summary: A case should be followed by a colon and not a semicolon.

switch_case_space.summary: Removes extra spaces between colon and case value.

switch_continue_to_break.summary: Switch case must not be ended with `continue` but with `break`.

codeSamples.from:
<?php
switch ($foo) {
    case 1:
        while($bar) {
            do {
                continue 3;
            } while(false);

            if ($foo + 1 > 3) {
                continue;
            }

            continue 2;
        }
}
codeSamples.to:
<?php
switch ($foo) {
    case 1:
        while($bar) {
            do {
                break 3;
            } while(false);

            if ($foo + 1 > 3) {
                continue;
            }

            break 2;
        }
}

ternary_to_elvis_operator.summary: Use the Elvis operator `?:` where possible.
ternary_to_elvis_operator.riskyDescription: Risky when relying on functions called on both sides of the `?` operator.

codeSamples.from: <?php $foo = $bar[a()] ? $bar[a()] : 1; # "risky" sample, "a()" only gets called once after fixing
codeSamples.to: <?php $foo = $bar[a()] ?  : 1; # "risky" sample, "a()" only gets called once after fixing

trim_array_spaces.summary: Arrays should be formatted like function/method arguments, without leading or trailing single line space.

visibility_required.summary: Classes, constants, properties, and methods MUST have visibility declared, and keyword modifiers MUST be in the following order: inheritance modifier (`abstract` or `final`), visibility modifier (`public`, `protected`, or `private`), set-visibility modifier (`public(set)`, `protected(set)`, or `private(set)`), scope modifier (`static`), mutation modifier (`readonly`), type declaration, name.

{

    protected string $foo;

    static protected int $beep;

    static public final function bar() {}

    protected abstract function zim();

    function zex() {}
}

}

void_return.summary: Add `void` return type to functions with missing or empty return statements, but priority is given to `@return` annotations.

configuration.name: ensure_single_space
configuration.description: If there are only horizontal whitespaces after the comma then ensure it is a single space.

whitespace_after_comma_in_array.summary: In array declaration, there MUST be a whitespace after each comma.

yield_from_array_to_yields.summary: Yield from array must be unpacked to series of yields.
yield_from_array_to_yields.description: The conversion will make the array in `yield from` changed in arrays of 1 less dimension.
yield_from_array_to_yields.riskyDescription: The rule is risky in case of `yield from` being used multiple times within single function scope, while using list-alike data sources (e.g. `function foo() { yield from ["a"]; yield from ["b"]; }`). It only matters when consuming such iterator with key-value context, because set of yielded keys may be changed after applying this rule.

configuration.name: always_move_variable
configuration.description: Whether variables should always be on non assignable side when applying Yoda style.

configuration.name: equal
configuration.description: Style for equal (`==`, `!=`) statements.

configuration.name: identical
configuration.description: Style for identical (`===`, `!==`) statements.

configuration.name: less_and_greater
configuration.description: Style for less and greater than (`<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`) statements.

yoda_style.summary: Write conditions in Yoda style (`true`), non-Yoda style (`['equal' => false, 'identical' => false, 'less_and_greater' => false]`) or ignore those conditions (`null`) based on configuration.

codeSamples.to:
<?php
    // Enforce non-Yoda style.
    if ($a === null) {
        echo "null";
    }
